item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Second big question. This lab churned out untrustworthy research. Yet according to publication and citation data, as well as his appointment, the field basically elected him leader.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Did nobody in the field notice the work was unreliable? Is it possible that this unreliable work was no worse or maybe still better than most of the rest of the field's production?

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Rather than neurodegeneration research accumulating carefully validated results, this gives the impression of a field barely treading water in a swamp of untrustworthy work.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: In this context, James Heather's recent estimate that 1/7 papers contains falsified or fabricated results suddenly seems very plausible. (I read the preprint and believe the estimate is plausible.)https://osf.io/s4gce

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: James also asked whether cheats might be more prolific than honest researchers. And of course, like here, they are. Almost by definition - people cheat for speed.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Third big question. What are NIH going to do about their huge procedural weaknesses this affair reveals?

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: For NIH-funded researchers, the organisation usually seems quite unintersted in integrity issues, beyond emitting incantations about "taking integrity issues very seriously" after every new scandal.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Here, somewhat surprisingly, NIH had carried out some sort of investigation, presumably following initial posts on PubPeer. Perhaps the in-house employment and high-ranking position of Masliah caught their attention and obliged them to do something.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Nevertheless, a combination of PubPeer, an alert Charles Piller and a couple of volunteer analysts ran rings and looped loops around the NIH investigation, which only looked at 2 papers. Official investigations are crap, again.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Reading between the lines, it seems that NIH are scrambling to adjust to the new information they failed to investigate and were not planning a severe response, since Masliah was still representing the organisation this week. This remains to be clarified.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: The levels of wasted human and financial resources, the potential corruption of science and its administration are significant. Masliah operated with impunity. NIH procedures are totally ineffective at detecting or deterring career-long, industrial-scale cheating.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: In fact, convince me that NIH procedures don't in practice facilitate and encourage such cheating. After all, they regularly funded and then hired Masliah.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Fourth big question. Conflicts of interest. I assume (but don't know) that Masliah wound up his lab upon taking the NIA job. But, without suggesting any specific transactions, it seems likely that Masliah's position might have influenced (negatively) desire to report his misconduct.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Similarly, the industry pursuit of multiple therapeutic strategies based upon his work could well have been influenced (positively) by his position. Did he retain a direct financial interest in these? Is this a CoI to be managed? Is it managed?

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Fifth big question. When will the clinical trials unethically based upon unreliable work be halted?

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: A few loose ends. NIH don't want to screen for misconduct when they hire people, because of the "difficulty of the process". I'm going to predict it would be a whole lot easier and more effective if they hired Mu Yang and Matthew Schrag (or several other analysts).

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: And, of course, there is a pile of public information on PubPeer just waiting to be "discovered" and acted upon by officialdom. As this affair shows, pulling on the thread of a couple of PubPeer comments sometimes (mixing my metaphors) opens a whole can of worms.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Science EiC Holden Thorp (who has a good record on dealing with misconduct) gave an unfortunately nonchalant quote about seeking a "response" from the authors and making "adjustments" to a paper if "required".

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: There is an alarmingly naive quote from a researcher in the field suggesting the synuclein antibody strategy might still be effective. People cheat for a reason, and random curative treatment strategies do not have a 50% chance of working.

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: Finally, congratulations to Charles Piller, his collaborators and all of the unrewarded analysts who brought this affair to light.
